journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Design, modeling, and optimization of a thermally activated reconfigurable wing system

article-meta.aff: 1Aerospace Mechanics Division of UDRI, University of Dayton Research Institute, Dayton, OH, USA
2Aerospace Systems Directorate within AFRL, Air Force Research Laboratory, Dayton, OH, USA

author-notes.corresp: Richard Beblo, University of Dayton Research Institute, 300 College Park, Dayton, OH 45469, USA. Email: Richard.Beblo@wpafb.af.mil

abstract.p: Reconfigurable structures such as morphing aircraft generally require an on-board energy source to function. At high speeds, however, frictional heating generated at the nose of a morphing aircraft can provide a large amount of thermal energy during a short period of time. This thermal energy can be collected, transferred, and utilized to reconfigure the aircraft. Direct utilization of thermal energy has the ability to significantly decrease or eliminate the losses associated with converting thermal energy to other forms, such as electric. The following work describes possible system designs and components that can be utilized to transfer the thermal energy harvested at the nose of the aircraft to internal components for direct thermal actuation of a reconfigurable wing structure. Previously reported topology optimized heat collectors, vehicle trajectories, and the deployment mechanism are combined with the presented analytical model of a heat pipe for a system level model used to optimize the system based on weight and the desired wing deployment time.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The following work studied the means and feasibility of a thermally based wing deployment system, as illustrated in Figure 1. With the intent of gaining the ability to have an intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) asset in place anywhere in the world as quickly as possible, it has been proposed that an ISR asset, which is typically optimized for endurance rather than speed, be packaged and transported to the desired location via a high-speed transport vehicle. This is very similar to the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) Rapid Eye concept, except that in this instance, the delivery is done in the atmosphere, rather than by ballistic missile (DARPA, 2007). Once released from the transport, the packaged unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) would undergo frictional aerodynamic heating as it decreased in altitude and speed. This thermal energy can be harvested and used to deploy the wings and/or empennage of the aircraft, reducing both the required on-board power and the time between when the need for the ISR is realized and when the transport vehicle is launched.

caption.p: Operational overview of notional ISR delivery system.
ISR: intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance.

sec.p: Passive systems, such as the one described here, are historically more reliable than their active counterparts due to their relative simplicity as well as the reliability of components. For the studied application of deploying the wings of a released UAV, reliability of the deployment mechanism is of the utmost importance.

sec.title: System concept
sec.p: The system described in this report consists of a packaged low-speed UAV, with the wings and tail folded, that is transported via a high-speed delivery vehicle to the desired location. The UAV is then released at a specified speed and altitude and experiences frictional aerodynamic heating. This thermal energy is collected at the nose of the aircraft and transported to various locations by a heat pipe. The thermal energy is then transferred to a shape memory polymer (SMP) link in a bistable mechanism, allowing a preloaded spring actuator to deploy the wings and/or tail of the vehicle. For the feasibility study presented, only the deployment of the wings is directly considered. It is understood that the empennage could also be deployed with a similar system. Notional diagrams of the systems’ major components and thermal energy flow are included as Figures 2 and 3.

caption.p: Conceptual vehicle configuration.
Flow diagram of thermal system.

sec.p: One of the critical factors in determining the feasibility of a direct use thermal system is the amount of time and heat available between when the UAV is released from the transport vehicle and when thermal energy ceases to be generated due to lack of speed. While it is likely that the future actual vehicle will differ from the notional vehicle presented here, the analysis itself is required as a reference to design the thermal system. This analysis provides optimization points, namely, a desired time for the wings to deploy, that the thermal system can be optimized for given the chosen trajectory.

To calculate an expected trajectory of the UAV after release from the transport vehicle, several assumptions must be made. First, the vehicle is assumed to be trimmed at all times. It is assumed to have a lift to drag ratio of 2, a drag coefficient of 1.0, and is initially at uniform ambient temperature. The vehicle is assumed to be cylindrical with a diameter of 1 m, is 5 m long, weighs 300 kg, and has a spherically shaped nosecone. While this is a gross simplification, it represents a possible real system as realistically as is feasible given the notional nature of the investigation. With these assumptions, the altitude and speed of the vehicle can be calculated at any given time. More details of the analysis and resulting possible trajectories are presented in an earlier article (Beblo et al., 2010).

In the absence of a reference transport vehicle, the nominal trajectory resulting from the release of the UAV at an altitude of 30 km traveling Mach 5 was chosen for analysis purposes. Such a trajectory results in a reasonable amount of thermal energy generation while remaining feasible from a transport vehicle standpoint. This chosen reference trajectory results in about 148 s of thermal energy harvesting between release and the point at which the UAV has slowed to Mach 1.

If the speed, altitude, and vehicle characteristics are known, or in this case assumed, the thermal energy available for harvesting can be directly calculated. The aerodynamic heating as a result of the formation of a bow shock at supersonic speeds is calculated based on the characteristics of the stagnation properties of air behind the shock wave at the nose of the vehicle (Anderson, 1989). Calculation of the heat flux into the vehicle is accomplished by the method described by Eckert (1961) by calculating an effective heat transfer coefficient and reference temperature at the stagnation point of the flow at the nose of the aircraft. The heat flux distribution over the entire nose of the vehicle is then calculated based on Lees’ (1956) method by calculating the ratio of the heat flux at a given point with respect to the heat flux at the stagnation point for a hemispherical body. Resulting heat flux distributions over the nose of the vehicle with respect to angle at various speeds are shown in Figure 4. More details of the analysis are presented in a previous article (Beblo et al., 2010).

caption.p: Heat flux ratio over a blunt nosecone at various speeds.

sec.p: The result of the trajectory and thermal analysis is a comprehensive look at the energy and time requirements of the thermal system. The analysis provides a definitive amount of thermal energy, given a release altitude and speed, which is available for harvesting. Any energy ultimately available to deploy the wings of the vehicle is then a function of the efficiency of the system itself. The analysis also sets a specific desired time for the wings to deploy. To limit the aerodynamic forces on the wings, it is desired that they deploy as late as possible, when the vehicle is traveling slowly. With this knowledge, a direct use thermal system can be designed to passively deploy the wings at the specified time.

The following work details the steps and considerations taken to design the system for optimal performance. Given the complexity of the system and governing equations, an iterative approach is taken, with each component of the system dependent on the optimization of the previous component. The two main constraints on the system are the desired wing deployment time, dictated by the trajectory, and the total weight of the system. The design variables adjusted to reach the desired constraints include the vehicle nose shape, thermal collection area size, heat pipe characteristics (dimensions and internal pressure), SMP link dimensions and material, and the bistable mechanism dimensions. Other variables affecting the system but not directly treated here include vehicle aerodynamics (lift and drag), vehicle weight, heat pipe materials, vehicle thermal protection systems, cooling of the SMP link, and so on.

sec.title: Vehicle aerodynamics and characteristics
sec.p: While the presented case is for a spherically shaped nose, where the shock wave stands off the vehicle, the thermal energy generated can be significantly increased with a more pointed nose shape, shown in Figure 5. The closer the bow shock is to the vehicle, the higher the heat transfer rate.

caption.p: Effect of nosecone shape on induced shock wave (NASA, 1952).

sec.p: A similar effect is seen by reducing the diameter of the vehicle, as shown in Figure 6. Reducing the diameter from 1.5 to 0.5 m while holding all other vehicle characteristics constant results in an increase in the maximum temperature of the surface of the vehicle from 75°C to more than 240°C; indicated by the solid line in Figure 6. More drastic, however, is the increase in the total energy transferred to the flexible link; increasing from about 50 kJ to almost 1500 kJ, shown by the dashed line in Figure 6. In addition to the nose shape’s influence on the shock wave, another main reason for the increase in harvested energy is the flight time of the vehicle before slowing below Mach 1. All other variables held constant, a 1.5-m-diameter vehicle slows to Mach 1 in just 47 s, while a 0.5-m-diameter vehicle takes 240 s to reach Mach 1. Thus, the aerodynamics of the vehicle must also be considered when optimizing the proposed direct use thermal system.

caption.p: Effect of vehicle diameter on harvestable thermal energy.

sec.p: Also note that this result is for a purely ballistic vehicle. Any vehicle control that would allow for different trajectories would enable designers to modify and optimize a transient thermal energy pattern by actively controlling the vehicle speed and altitude during descent.

Increasing the mass of the vehicle has a similar effect on the thermal energy transferred, although slightly less drastic, since the increased mass results in a higher momentum when released from the transport vehicle, leading to longer flight times. If the mass of the vehicle is increased from 200 to 400 kg, the thermal energy transferred to the link increases from 290 to 1400 kJ, shown by the dashed line in Figure 7.

caption.p: Effect of vehicle mass on harvestable thermal energy.

sec.p: While all the aforementioned vehicle parameters affect the amount of thermal energy delivered to the wing actuation mechanism, they also greatly affect other factors such as the overall vehicle speed, payload capacity, and fuel efficiency. Thus, any implementation of the system will require careful integration into the vehicle.

sec.title: Thermal energy collection
sec.p: The first design consideration of the system is how to collect or harvest the thermal energy generated at the nose of the vehicle, for which two options are investigated. The first option is to use a highly conductive/lightweight material, such as a carbon-based material, to create an optimized thermal bridge between the curved surface of the nose and a central point within the vehicle. The second option is to use a flat plate loop style heat pipe contoured to the curvature of the nose.

A high-conductive material lacks the efficiency of a heat pipe and requires significantly more volume; however, it has the potential to be lighter. Details of the optimization of this type of collector are presented by Joo et al. (2010). Alternatively, heat pipes are extremely efficient at moving large amounts of thermal energy over long distances and would require less volume than a solid collector. Heat pipes, however, are extremely heavy (Hwang et al., 2007; Wang and Vafai, 2000; Zhu and Vafai, 1997).

sec.title: Optimized thermal bridge
sec.p: One of the possible solutions for collecting the thermal energy generated at the nose of the vehicle is a solid highly conductive material optimized for the given heat flux distribution. Although a specific material was not identified, the method used to ascertain the optimum distribution of the material remains applicable and is described here.

The blunt nose of the vehicle is subject to distributed heating during reentry, such as in Figure 4, and the temperature of the interior of the vehicle is assumed a constant 0°C. Heat energy generated at the surface of the nosecone is then modeled as conducted through the nose to the body of the vehicle, see inset in Figure 4. The fitness function and a more detailed derivation of the method are described in a previous publication (Joo et al., 2010).

Figure 8 shows the optimized conductor designs when 10%, 20%, 30%, 40%, 60%, and 80% of the available area is filled with the chosen material. As seen in this figure, the high-conductive material is distributed near the stagnation point on the nose because it is subject to higher heat flux than the rest of the area. Energy is collected by the distributed high-conductive material near the surface, directed toward the center, and then to the right edge to minimize resistance, taking the shortest path to the right edge with a large cross-sectional area. The two-dimensional design problem solved here shows sufficient detail of each design, but the method can easily be extended to three dimensions if needed using cubic elements.

caption.p: Optimized collector designs for various material area fractions.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 8, the area of the nose where thermal energy is collected varies by the area fraction of material utilized. The 10% area fraction case covers approximately a third of the nose area, while the 80% area fraction case covers nearly the entire surface of the nose. The choice of what area fraction is ultimately required depends upon the amount of thermal energy available with the chosen trajectory, the amount of thermal energy required by the wing deployment mechanism to operate in the allotted time, and the thermal efficiency of the system.

The largest advantage of a high-conductive material thermal collector is the possible weight savings over a flat plate heat pipe collector. Highly conductive carbon fiber (CF) composites and ceramics can be made to be relatively lightweight, which is extremely important on endurance optimized UAVs. Given sufficient initial speed and altitude, it is possible that only 10% or less of the vehicle’s nosecone volume would need to be filled with such a material, resulting in minimal volume and weight penalizations of the system.

sec.title: Flat plate heat pipe collector
sec.p: The second option for collecting the thermal energy available at the nose of the vehicle is a flat plate heat pipe contoured to the inner surface of the UAV’s nose. For this option, the governing heat equations are the same as those derived in later sections. Given the same vehicle trajectory as described previously, equations (1) to (36) can be used to calculate the thermal energy collected by the heat pipe for various collection area sizes, shown in Figure 9. Since the heat flux generated by the shock wave is concentrated at the tip of the vehicle, the energy available for harvesting is nearly undiminished until the collector area is reduced to below 50% of the nosecone area with the collector centered around the stagnation point.

caption.p: Harvested energy with respect to heat collection area.

sec.p: The design considerations resulting from the above analysis if a flat plate heat pipe is used to collect thermal energy at the nose of the vehicle include the heat pipe wall thickness, wick thickness and porosity, working fluid, internal vapor chamber pressure, and materials. It is also required that the size of the collection area be chosen at this stage in the analysis. Since a closed-form solution to the optimum heat collector size is unavailable, the collector size is assumed and the system is optimized iteratively. It should also be noted that the above design variables are not independent. For example, the minimum wall thickness is a function of the selected materials and maximum pressure experienced by the heat pipe, which is a function of the working fluid and maximum temperature.

sec.title: Thermal energy transportation
sec.p: The second design consideration is how to transport the collected thermal energy to various points within the vehicle. Due to the limited time frame and the distance between the collection and utilization points, efficiency in this stage is paramount. Thus, a heat pipe is utilized for this purpose, the analysis and modeling of which is presented here.

sec.title: Heat pipe construction
sec.p: Heat pipes, an example of which is shown in Figure 10, typically consist of a metal outer wall material, an inner porous sintered powdered metal material acting as a wick, an empty vapor chamber, and a working fluid. Heat enters the heat pipe at any location (referred to as the evaporator section) and causes the working fluid held in the wick to vaporize. Local differences in pressure then force the high-temperature vapor to cooler areas within the vapor chamber. The vapor then condenses, transferring thermal energy to this cooler area of the heat pipe (referred to as the condenser section). The condensed working fluid is then pulled toward high-temperature areas via capillary pressures. Heat pipes have been shown to work in environments of extremely high external inertial forces and through various wall, wick, and working fluid choices can operate in temperatures between −271°C and 2300°C (Shankara-Narayanan, 2011).

caption.p: Modulated wick heat pipe (Hwang et al., 2007).

sec.p: In the current design, either a flat plate heat pipe would be contoured to the interior of the nosecone with a single wick on the hot side of the heat pipe (the collector described previously) or the end of a traditional heat pipe would be connected to the high-conductive material collector. The vapor generated would then be channeled through an insulated pipe to the bistable mechanism used for wing deployment. There are several factors that influence the thermal energy transmitted by the heat pipe, only some of which are investigated here. Methods such as complicated wick geometries pictured in Figure 10 can dramatically increase the transfer of thermal energy. Other factors such as the packing fraction of the wick, working fluids with different viscosities, and vapor channel size effect the thermal performance of the heat pipe.

sec.title: Heat pipe thermal model
sec.p: To accurately determine the amount and rate of thermal energy delivered to the link, a thermal model capturing the transient response of the heat pipe is used. An accurate representation of the thermal energy transmitted to the link, then, allows for the design of the deployment mechanism and flexible link for the desired wing deployment time.
A schematic showing the parts of a flat plate heat pipe is shown in Figure 11. Neglecting the curvature of the nosecone, the heat flow into the heat pipe is assumed to be one dimensional.

caption.p: Heat pipe schematic.

sec.p: To estimate heat flow, the solution to the one-dimensional heat equation is found using the method of orthogonal eigenfunctions as described by De Monte (2000). The solution is

where θ is a temperature difference defined by the boundary conditions, k is the thermal conductivity, α is the thermal diffusivity, λ are the eigenvalues, and t is the time. The constants Cm and Nm are determined from the orthogonality condition and are given as follows
where F is related to the initial temperature distribution and L is the layer thickness. The eigenvectors are
The eigenvalues are defined by

The only parameters that change with the boundary conditions are then
Π
1 , m
and
Π
′
2 , m
. Due to the nature of the method and to cancel terms, only certain sets of boundary conditions can be modeled. Solutions to ill-suited sets of boundary conditions are then solved by superposition. The three sets of boundary conditions used in this study are listed below. Boundary condition set A describes a system with a Robin equation governing heat into the system on one boundary and zero heat flux out of the system on the other or an insulated Neumann condition. Boundary condition set B describes a system having constant temperature, or Dirichlet, boundary conditions on both boundaries. Boundary condition set C describes the system with a Dirichlet condition on one edge (constant temperature) and a zero heat flux Neumann condition on the other.
which result in the quantities:

where h is a coefficient of convective heat transfer, T is the temperature, f is the initial temperature distribution, and the subscripts 1 and 2 refer to the wall and wick layers of the heat pipe, respectively. Quantities with a subscript i are valid for both the wall and wick (i.e. i is both subscripts 1 and 2), Tstag is the stagnation point temperature, and Tboil is the current boiling temperature of the working fluid.

When the temperature at the wick–vapor interface (i.e. x = L2) is below boiling, the heat flux across this boundary is assumed to be negligible and is set to 0 (equation (11)). Thus, the equations resulting from boundary condition set A are used to solve for the temperature distribution for the current time step. If the temperature at the wick–vapor interface is above boiling, the heat flux is not negligible, and the resulting temperature distribution is found by adding boundary condition set B and subtracting set C from set A. This in effect fixes the temperature at the boundary at x = L2 and solves for the resulting heat flux.

The heat pipe is modeled as a bilayer composite in both the evaporator and condenser sections. In the evaporator section, the wall and wick of the heat pipe are modeled as a solid material and a porous material with effective thermal properties, respectively. For simplicity, the flexible link is modeled as a hollow cylinder replacing the copper wall in the condenser section modeling the bistable mechanism.

As the temperature of the heat pipe rises, the working fluid in the wick vaporizes, adding vapor to the vapor chamber. This vapor is then directed toward the condenser section by pressure differences where it condenses. An imbalance in the amount of vapor entering the vapor chamber and the amount exiting the vapor chamber causes a net increase or decrease of pressure in the heat pipe. An increase in pressure causes the boiling temperature of the working fluid to increase and the reverse with a decrease in pressure. To accurately model the heat flow through the system, this change in boiling temperature must be accounted for as it retards the flow of thermal energy by increasing the temperature of the evaporator section. The mass of vapor entering the heat pipe is calculated by the amount of energy in Joules divided by the latent heat of vaporization. As shown in previous studies (Wang and Vafai, 2000; Zhu and Vafai, 1997) and employed here, the amount of vapor condensing in the condenser section can be estimated by the ratio of the volume of the condenser to the volume of the entire heat pipe. The change in pressure can then be calculated from the following relation

where Δ;P is the change in pressure, Δm is the change in mass of the vapor, R is the gas constant, Tvapor is the temperature of the vapor, VHP is the total volume of the heat pipe, and ω is the molar mass of the working fluid. The boiling temperature of the working fluid is then calculated with the Antoine (1988) equation
where Tboil is the boiling temperature of the working fluid in Kelvin and P is the pressure in Pascal.

Assuming a trajectory calculated from an initial speed and an altitude of Mach 5 and 30 km, respectively, and typical vehicle characteristics as described previously, and utilizing the results from modeling the thermal collection system, the temperature and heat flux at any point in the heat pipe at any time can be determined and are shown in Figure 12. The graph shows the temperature on the outer surface of the vehicle (Ts) if a flat plate heat pipe is used as the collector, at the interface between the wall and wick of the heat pipe in the evaporator section near the nose of the vehicle (Tie), at the interface between the wick and the vapor chamber in the evaporator (Tv), at the interface between the vapor chamber and the heat pipe wall in the condenser section (Tc), at the interface between the wall and the flexible link (Tic), and at the interface between the active material of the link and the link casing (To). Due to the high conductivity and thin construction of the heat pipe wall, modeled here as copper, the change in temperature through the wall is minimal. In this case, the difference between Ts and Tie and the difference between Tc and Tic are nearly indistinguishable.

caption.p: Heat pipe temperatures resulting from a Mach 5, 30-km altitude trajectory.

sec.p: Finally, note that To, the external surface of the active material within the link, reaches the transition temperature of the polymer in approximately 105 s, well before the desired time of 148 s of the chosen trajectory. This is due to the system collecting and transmitting more thermal energy than is required. Reducing the amount of thermal energy transmitted can be achieved in several ways, including reducing the evaporator size, choosing a different trajectory, using different materials, and/or changing the design of the link.

sec.title: Thermal energy delivered to link
sec.p: With a known trajectory, known energy input profile, and known energy flows through the heat pipe, the exact amount and time and thermal energy available to the wing deployment mechanism can be determined. This information is then utilized to design and optimize the bistable compliant mechanism used to deploy the wings.

Among other factors, the amount of thermal energy delivered to the link is directly affected by the collection area, shown in Figure 13, increasing by 30% when the collection area is increased from 10% to 100% since the heat flux over the nose of the vehicle is nonuniform.

caption.p: Energy delivered to link with respect to heat collection area.

sec.p: A final detail in the thermal transport problem is the time required for the heat energy to reach its intended target and affect deployment of the wings. Figure 14 shows the time required for a simple cylindrical link heated from the interior surface to reach the transition temperature for VeriflexE, a representative SMP material, with respect to the thermal energy collector size. Intuitively, the shortest time occurs when energy is collected over the entire nose of the vehicle. However, for safety reasons and design robustness, it is not desired for the wings to deploy before the vehicle reaches Mach 1. This is because at high speeds, the increased aerodynamic drag could damage the wings. For this purpose, the thermal system acts as a built in delay mechanism that can be precisely calibrated to deploy the wings at a given time. If the area of the nose that thermal energy is collected is reduced to 25%–30%, the energy delivered to the link will cause the wings to deploy at approximately 150 s, which is precisely when the vehicle reaches Mach 1. Alternatively, the extra thermal energy available could be used for other purposes, such as deploying other structures or charging batteries.

caption.p: Time for link to fully transition with respect to heat collection area.

sec.title: SMP compliant link and bistable mechanism design
sec.p: The final consideration is the design of the SMP compliant link and the bistable mechanism used to deploy the wings of the aircraft (Figures 15 and 16). While shape memory alloys (SMAs) were considered for actuation, it was shown that more SMA materials than could be realistically heated would be required. Thus, a system where the thermal energy is used to trip a switch, which requires significantly less energy than an SMA actuation system, was selected.

caption.p: Bistable mechanism design.

Experimental validation of wing deployment mechanism. (a) Packaged position: when in the packaged position, the wing is fully enclosed in the body of the vehicle and the multifunctional link is in the stiff state; (b) wing deployment: during deployment, the link is soft, changing the stable configuration of the system, resulting in the motion of the wing; and (c) deployed position: after full deployment, the multifunctional link is allowed to cool, stiffening and stabilizing the system.

sec.p: Having an accurate measure of the thermal energy delivered to the link for the given trajectory, the link and mechanism can be optimized to deploy the wings at the desired time. In the presented design, the simultaneous softening and weakening of the SMP link upon heating allows a preloaded spring actuator to act on the linkage, deploying the wings. After deployment, the SMP link cools and stabilizes the wing in the deployed position at a sweep of approximately 17°. The analysis of the bistable mechanism, briefly described here, is detailed by Joo et al. (2010, 2011), including a potential energy analysis of the mechanism showing the stable positions as the temperature of the flexible link increases. The thermal properties and modeling of the link itself, also briefly described here, highlighting efforts to increase the diffusivity of the SMP material were previously published in detail (Beblo et al., 2011).

sec.title: SMP link geometry
sec.p: The conceptual design identified a heat-activated variable stiffness link made of a modulus switching material on the interior and an external covering material. The primary functions of the external covering are to protect the polymer from the environment and aid in supporting the aerodynamic loads during deployment when the SMP is soft. This can be accomplished with a custom-designed material if there is no commercial material available, potentially utilizing carbon fiber–reinforced polymer (CFRP).

The material for the inner portion of the link was chosen to be an epoxy-based SMP thermoplastic polymer. These polymer systems provide the ability to soften at elevated temperatures and become hardened or stiff at lower temperatures. The material used as a representative candidate in this study is Veriflex E2, from CRG Industries. The material satisfies the modulus switching requirement at a moderate glass transition (Tg) temperature of 104°C along with the added benefit of shape memory.

The design of a device to add thermal energy to the link is of great importance since Veriflex E2 and most other neat polymers have low thermal conductivity. There are a number of potential methods to impart this energy such as in Figure 17 (left), which is an optimized root-like structure similar to the heat collector described previously. The middle design in Figure 17 uses basic wires running lengthwise through the link, while the design on the right in Figure 17 is a continuous flat coil device. The design, spacing, and physical geometries of such concepts must provide thermal energy distributed evenly in the cross section. Forcing heated air through capillaries within the polymer has also been suggested as well as thin walled structures were geometry is used to achieve the desired link stiffness, such as a hollow cylinder, which is the design analyzed here.

caption.p: Thermal conductor design.

sec.p:
During initial deployment (Figure 16(a)), since the inner material of the cylindrical bilayer link is soft, the outer shell of the link is responsible for carrying any aerodynamic load on the wing. After “snap-through,” where the input arm (
r
→
2
in Figure 18) is in line with the wing (
r
→
3
in Figure 18) (Figure 16(b)), the force exerted on the link by aerodynamic drag on the wing is countered by the force exerted by the torsional actuator at the base of the input arm. Before snap-through, the input arm is pushing on the wing. After snap-through, the input arm is pulling on the wing. The counterbalancing of these forces reduces the load supported by the flexible link when aerodynamic drag is at a maximum and the wing is fully deployed (Figure 16(c)), thus reducing the size and required stiffness of the link.

caption.p: Bistable compliant mechanism equivalent slider–spring model.

sec.p: To deploy the wing, the torsional actuator must exert more force on the tip of the flexible link than the link can support with the SMP in the soft state. In the hard state, however, the flexible link must be able to counteract the force supplied by the torsional actuator to keep the wing in the packaged position. The active material in the core of the link provides this additional strength needed to maintain the packaged position of the wing.

The strength requirements of the link, of course, change with deployment speed and altitude which in turn is a function of the initial release speed and altitude, as well as the vehicle’s wingspan, chord, airfoil shape, mass, outer mold line, angle of attack, and wing sweep. Once the load requirements of the link are determined, the dimensions and required thermal properties of the link itself can be resolved. Due to the notional and feasibility nature of the study with many parameters only estimated, exact dimensions and materials of the flexible link are not investigated here.

As mentioned previously, due to the notional nature of the presented feasibility study and the fidelity of the thermal energy model, no attempt is made to describe the exact dimensions of the bistable mechanism or multifunctional link. Although an exact design adhering to material limitations was found to be possible, reporting such a detailed design detracts from the feasibility nature of the work.

sec.title: SMP link thermal properties
sec.p: One of the major hurdles when introducing SMP to any design is that the polymer has a low thermal diffusivity, and thus requires a significant amount of time to heat from ambient to its transition temperature. To mitigate the low thermal diffusivity, particle and fiber doping can be used to increase the thermal properties of the material as well as the mechanical properties.

For this study, magnetite nanoparticles and two lengths of CFs were chosen as candidate materials to investigate. Since the flexible link is envisioned to provide a degree of damping to the system as well, making the system advantageous not only for delivery of the vehicle but also over its entire in-theater service, a low-volume fraction of dopants is desired. High-volume fractions of particles and fibers tend to have adverse effects on the composite’s plasticity.

The magnetite (Fe3O4) nanoparticles were supplied by SkySpring Nanomaterials, Inc. and are 98%+ 20- to 30-nm-diameter approximate spheres. The 10-mm-long CF was supplied by Fibre Glast Developments Corporation in fabric form (6 K, 5 HS Weave Part #660), which was deconstructed and cut into 10 mm nominal lengths. The 3-mm chopped CF was supplied by Toho Tenax America, Inc. (Tenax®-A HT C124 3 mm) with a reported tensile modulus of 225 GPa, density of 1.82 g/cm3, and filament diameter of 7 µm.

The VeriflexE SMP resin was mixed per the manufacturer’s directions and then weighed. The appropriate weight of magnetite or CF was then incorporated by hand (10 wt% Fe3O4 and 5.4 wt% CF) for the desired 2.5 vol% composite. The composite was then left under medium vacuum (∼25″ Hg) for approximately 10 min to remove air bubbles introduced during mixing. The resin composite was then poured into various molds depending upon the desired test, treated with Epoxease Mold Release (Slide Products, Wheeling, IL) and 3145 RTV sealant (Dow Corning Corporation, Midland, MI). The filled mold was then placed back under vacuum for an additional 5 min. Finally, the mold was sealed and cured in a laboratory oven per the manufacturer’s suggested temperature profile.

The reported thermal properties of magnetite vary widely in published literature. Thermal conductivities ranging from 3.4 to 5.1 W/m K at room temperature have been reported (Clauser and Huenges, 1995; Horai and Simmons, 1969; Molgaard and Smeltzer, 1971), while ambient specific heat capacities (Cp) for magnetite range from 3.17e+6 to 3.60e+6 J/m3 K (Parks and Kelley, 1926; Razzaq et al., 2007; Westrum and Gronvold, 1969). This results in a thermal diffusivity in the range of 9.43e−7 to 1.61e−6 m2/s. Alternatively, CF has much higher thermal conductivity (116–593 W/m K) and much lower specific heat (between 1.8e+6 and 2.6e+6 J/m3 K) resulting in a thermal diffusivity between 4.46e−5 and 3.29e−4 m2/s (Philip et al., 2007).

Thermal properties of the neat VeriflexE as well as the magnetite and CF composites are measured using a Hot Disk Thermal Constants Analyser TPS 2500 S from ThermTest Inc. accurate to ±5%. Two cylindrical samples 0.5″ in diameter and 0.25″ in height are polished and a 4-mm diameter probe sandwiched between them to conduct the tests. The test specimens are held in a constant temperature thermal bath for at least 5 min before the start of the test at each temperature. Thermal properties of each specimen were measured at various temperatures between ambient (20°C) and well above Tg (140°C). The results of the thermal property tests at ambient and 140°C are shown in Tables 1 and 2.

caption.p: Experimental composite thermal properties at ambient.
Experimental composite thermal properties at 130°C.

sec.p: It should be noted that the measured thermal properties of the 10-mm CF composite are likely underestimated since the 4-mm probe tests the sample to a depth of 4 mm, so the effects of the entire 10-mm fiber is not accounted for. The thermal properties of the magnetite composite are also likely underestimated due to particle dispersion issues. Particle aggregates approximately 10–15 µm across were seen in the scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images of samples. Such groups of particles are approximately 330–750 particles across. It is presumed that no SMP is within the aggregates resulting in the particle groupings producing lower than optimum thermal properties.

From Tables 1 and 2, it is clear that the addition of CFs is significantly more effective at raising the thermal diffusivity of the polymer than magnetite nanoparticles. Although the increase in thermal properties due to the magnetite particles is likely underestimated due to the particle dispersion issue, as mentioned previously, it is unlikely that ideal dispersion would be as effective as CF.

The diffusivity is relatively constant below Tg for each sample and then transitions to a lower constant value above Tg. The diffusivity of VeriflexE and the magnetite composite reduce by approximately 35%, while the 3-mm and 10-mm CF composites reduce by 30% and 24%, respectively. As is noted from the one-dimensional heat equation, it is the diffusivity that most significantly influences the transient temperature profile in a material. Since there is a large difference in thermal diffusivity above and below Tg, assuming the diffusivity to be constant can lead to large errors in the predicted temperature profile as well as the thermal energy required to bring the material from ambient to above Tg.

Accounting for the changes in the thermal properties of the SMP link with respect to temperature results in a more accurate prediction of the thermal energy and time required for the link to soften and the wings of the vehicle to deploy. More details of the temperature dependence of the thermal properties of VeriflexE and how they were modeled were presented previously (Beblo et al., 2011).

sec.title: Wing deployment mechanism
sec.p: The mechanism used for deploying the wings is also a function of the wing loading; the design of which is optimized simultaneously with the compliant link. A nonmonolithic compliant mechanism has been chosen for the reconfigurable wing mechanism design due to its simple and multifunctional nature. A nonmonolithic compliant mechanism is a mechanism composed of both rigid and compliant links. It uses both the rigid body rotation at the hinges and the elastic deformation of compliant members to transfer force and motion. The wing is initially packaged in a folded position for transport. After release from the transport vehicle, thermal energy created at the nose of the vehicle is directed toward a multifunctional link, shown in red in Figure 15, consisting of a partially load bearing external covering and SMP hollow core. Once the link is softened, the pretensioned spring acts on the mechanism deploying the wing. The energy method used to optimize the deployment mechanism allows for the precise design of the lengths of each member, initial and final angles, and material property and load bearing requirements ensuring the mechanism operates in the desired fashion at the desired time.

An equivalent linear spring with slider system of the mechanism, used for modeling, with initial positions is shown in Figure 18. Most of the symbols used in the following equations are identified in Figure 18.

The potential energy of the mechanism is represented by a combination of the deformation of the torsional spring and the linear spring,
ϕ
2 and δ, respectively.
The torque applied to deform the mechanism is then

The stable positions can be found when either the potential energy is zero (
ϕ
2 = 0) or the first and second derivatives of the potential energy are zero and positive, respectively. Without a second stable position, the mechanism will return to the unfolded position (
ϕ
2 = 0) if no external load exists, shown in Figure 19 with Young’s modulus of the flexible link member of 0.5 MPa. If the flexible link is stiff, however, a second stable position occurs. The existence and position of stable points depends on the stiffness of the torsional spring, K2, and the bending stiffness of the variable stiffness link, K4. There are many possible combinations of K2 and the size of the flexible link, ri and ro, that determines K4. Therefore, a multifunctional optimization is suggested here to solve this problem.

caption.p: Change in mechanism potential energy with respect to Young’s modulus.

sec.p:
From a given design space for the wing mechanism, the length of the link
r
→
3
, the inner and outer radii of the flexible link, and the stiffness of the torsional spring are the design variables to be determined. The first term in the objective function is to make an extra stable point at lower temperatures by maximizing the hill
(
W
1
stiff
)
and minimizing the valley
(
W
2
stiff
)
. The second term is to eliminate the extra stable point at elevated temperatures by the opposite scheme to the first term. The optimization problem is solved under four constraints; the geometric boundary condition for external covering material, the maximum deflection, the geometric condition for
r
→
2
, and the buckling constraint.

A resulting potential energy plot of the mechanism is shown in Figure 19, which shows how the mechanism potential energy changes with respect to the rotation angle of link 2 for several values of modulus of the link. At lower temperatures, the potential energy curve has two stable points as intended at
ϕ
2 = 0° and
ϕ
2 = 62°. When the wing is packaged at
ϕ
2 = 62°, the mechanism is in a state of minimum energy and can hold the position without external torque when the flexible link is in its hard state. As the flexible link is heated, the stable position (or position of minimum energy) moves, and the energy hill between the two minima decreases.

Figure 20 is an enlargement of Figure 19 near the packaged position of
ϕ
2 = 62°. As the modulus of the flexible link decreases with temperature, not only does the energy hill between the two minima decrease but the stable position of minimum energy also shifts to the left, decreasing
ϕ
2. The path of the mechanism is indicated with circles in Figure 20. This slow shift continues at a rate relative to the rate of heating until
ϕ
2 approximately equals 30°, at which point the temperature is such that the link is fully transitioned to the soft state and the energy barrier inhibiting the rotation of link 2 in Figure 18 disappears. At this point, the wing rapidly deploys with
ϕ
2 decreasing from 30° to the deployed position of 0°.

caption.p: Thermal initiation of mechanism morphing.

sec.title: Thermal model validation
sec.p: To validate the thermal heat pipe model, an experimental setup was constructed of a commercially available heat pipe, shown in Figure 21. The dimensions of the heat pipe are listed in Table 3.

caption.p: Experimental heat pipe parameters.
Experimental heat pipe setup with insulation removed.

sec.p: A solid copper shoe 40 mm long was fitted with eight electrical resistive heaters (200 W maximum) driven at 150 W comprising the evaporator section of the heat pipe. The remaining 284 mm was insulated and 11 evenly spaced thermocouples over the length of the heat pipe attached to measure surface temperature.

To calibrate the model, the wick thickness in the evaporator was modeled as approximately 25% of the measured experimental value. The discrepancy between the physical experimental setup and the thermal model is believed to be dominated by the location of boiling, although other sources of error include the power supplied to the heaters, thermal energy input into the heat pipe, and temperature measurements. Most of the boiling occurs at the interface between the wall and wick, where the wick is hottest. The thermal energy does not have to diffuse into the wick. Vapor formed at the interface moves through the wick to the vapor chamber relatively unimpeded in the form of bubbles. After calibration, the temperature profile calculated by the model closely matched that of the experimental data shown in Figure 22.

caption.p: Experimental validation of heat pipe thermal model.

sec.title: Kinematic model validation
sec.p: A bench top test rig of the reconfigurable system was constructed to both demonstrate the concept and validate the kinematic model of the system. The demonstrator consists of a 12.7-mm-diameter cylindrical sample link made of neat SMP, wing components manufactured from aluminum, bearings, a Nichrome heater connected to a 90-V power source, a torsional spring, and a load cell. The cylindrical SMP link is wrapped with the Nichrome heater so that heat is conducted from the outside surface to the center of the link. The mechanism is assembled with pin and bearing joints to minimize friction and mounted to a modular T-slot frame allowing for adjustment, see Figure 16. When the wing is in the folded stable position (Figure 16(a)), the torsional spring is in a compressed state. The SMP is then heated to approximately 100°C and the link softens, allowing the spring to act on the mechanism (Figure 16(b)), causing the wing to deploy. The mechanism stops when the second bistable position is reached (Figure 16(c)).

If the energy delivered to the link by the Nichrome heater is scaled to match that calculated by the thermal heat pipe model, similar to Figure 12, the angle of the input arm of the demonstrator versus time results in Figure 23.

caption.p: Experimental mechanism actuation.

sec.p: The wing becomes fully deployed at about 155 s, which correlates well with the desired wing deployment time when the simulated vehicle slows to Mach 1. It should also be noted that the wing remains packaged until approximately 120 s after the heater is turned on, protecting the wings from damage at high speeds.

sec.title: System level design
sec.p: With the model describing the kinematics of the deployment mechanism, the entire system can be represented mathematically. To solve for the optimum system configuration, an iterative approach is taken. Starting with the chosen vehicle release speed and altitude, the vehicle’s physical parameters are prescribed including weight, length, width, chord, and nosecone shape, which can then be used to approximate aerodynamic quantities such as lift and drag. The ballistic trajectory of the UAV is then generated and used to calculate the time-dependent heat flux available for harvesting at the nose of the vehicle. Assuming a flat plate heat pipe collector, the area of the nose utilized for energy harvesting, heat pipe dimensions and materials, and initial conditions are used to calculate the thermal energy harvested, transported, and delivered to the link. The time history of energy delivered to the link is then used to design the bistable mechanism and new link based on the mechanical requirements of the deployment system. The process is then repeated, altering various design variables, until a minimum weight system is obtained that adheres to the time requirements of the chosen trajectory.

For the given trajectory with a release speed of Mach 5 and altitude of 30 km, stated vehicle dimensions and mass, and a limitation of a spherically shaped nose, the above analysis results in a system with a flat plate heat pipe collector approximately 30% of the entire nosecone area. The heat pipe has 2-mm-thick walls, 3-mm-thick wick, a working fluid of water, and a 1-cm vapor chamber. The SMP link is 0.5 m long and is a bilayer hollow cylindrical cylinder. The bistable mechanism pictured in Figure 18 has a torsional spring actuator weighing about 1.8 kg (4 lb). With various assumptions for materials, the flat plate heat pipe collector would weigh approximately 23 kg (51 lb), the pipe used to transport heated steam from the vehicle nose to the deployment mechanism 1 kg (2.2 lb), the SMP link and covering 0.05 kg (0.1 lb), and the remaining members and components of the mechanism approximately 1.5 kg (3.3 lb). The total weight of the system, optimized for the assumed trajectory, including the collector, heat pipe, SMP link, deployment mechanism and spring actuator, then, is approximately 30 kg (66 lb). However, the percent change in empty weight of the vehicle will depend heavily on the particular application.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The presented work investigated the feasibility of using a direct use thermal system to deploy the wings of a low-speed ISR asset after being transported to the desired location and released via a high-speed vehicle. The resulting system level thermal and kinematic model shows that there is enough energy to accomplish the task, which can be done using a multi-functional compliant mechanism having structural benefits after deployment. The resulting weight of the system based on a nominal trajectory, approximately 30 kg, is low enough as to warrant the systems’ further investigation. Although this study does not investigate in great detail the design of the system due to the early stage of development and notional nature of the work, the results are believed to be relatively accurate and justifiable.

The study also highlights that one of the critical elements in integrating such a system is the system level design of the aerodynamics of the vehicle. Particularly, the shape of the nose plays a critical role in the amount of thermal energy available for harvesting, which in turn dictates the overall weight of the system. When evaluating such a system, it is important to note peripheral benefits, such as the reduction or elimination of a thermal protection system, since the system is designed to move heat away from the hottest part of the vehicle. Ultimately, the benefit of the system must be weighed against the added weight and complexity to the vehicle over a more traditional active wing deployment system. While it has been shown to be feasible, much more research is needed to deploy the system, which is heavily integrated into the aerodynamics and structure of the vehicle.
